src: \textbf{{väitst}} dyy  va\textsuperscript{u}t  diinə    fryy  feelə    deed?
trs: Do you know what problem your wife has?’\footnote{Cf. non-standard \ili{German} (constructed) \textit{Weißt du, was deiner Frau fehlen tut?}} \citep[170]{Jedig2014}
Are you crazy?’\footnote{Colloquially, \ili{German} also has the adjective \textit{meschugge} ‘crazy’.}
Do you want tea or coffee?
Do you want tea or not?

whether I can cure his wife’ \citep[170]{Jedig2014}\footnote{The \isi{word order} of \ili{Plautdiitsch} is also possible in \ili{German} but sounds very archaic. A \ili{German} equivalent would be something like the following: \textit{ob ich seine Frau heilen kann}.}
I wonder whether it will rain.
I wonder who that will be.
Did the student answer all the questions?
Was it the student who answered all the questions?’ (\citealt{SussexCubberley2006}: 359)

src: ty buv u teatri, \textbf{{čy}} v muzej{i?}
trs: Were you at the theater or in the museum?’ \citep[978]{Shevelov1993}
Do you want tea or coffee?’ \citep[23]{Comrie1984}

src: za vashe    zh’onusheki  mes’aca  posidi  esa?
trs: Do you sit together with your wives?
What do you want in my tent?’ \citep[361]{Stern2012}

imt: 2\textsc{sg}  say.3\textsc{sg} mother  hither    \textsc{neg}  let.\textsc{inf}  \textsc{aux.fut} or  what=\textsc{q}
src: ty  govorit,  mama  əmədja    ne  puskat  budem, \textbf{ili}  \textbf{čego=li}?
trs: Are you saying that we should not let mother come here or what?’ \citep[310]{Stern2005}
Can you keep the regulations of the laywomen?’ (\citealt{Emmerick1985}: 10f., 14)

src: cämpäl=\textbf{{te}} nasan    cesäm    wrasaśśi  waste mäskatsi, \textbf{{m\=a=te}} cämpäl      (\textbf{{na}})  sam?
trs: Am I able to provide refuge to the beings or am I not able?’ \citep[113]{Hackstein2013}
Will the master not keep this Brahman or will he not keep us?’ \citep[113]{Hackstein2013}
You are the new one, aren’t you?
What kind of holiday is this?
What kind of holiday is this?’ (\citealt{JacobsPrincevanderAuwera1994}: 413)
